description:
Energy-conservative high school student Houtarou Oreki ends up with more than he bargained for when he signs up for the Classic Literature Club at his sister's behest—especially when he realizes how deep-rooted the club's history really is. Begrudgingly, Oreki is dragged into an investigation concerning the 45-year-old mystery that surrounds the club room.

Accompanied by his fellow club members, the knowledgeable Satoshi Fukube, the stern but benign Mayaka Ibara, and the ever-curious Eru Chitanda, Oreki must combat deadlines and lack of information with resourcefulness and hidden talent, in order to not only find the truth buried beneath the dust of works created years before them, but of other side cases as well.

Based on the award-winning Koten-bu light novel series, and directed by Yasuhiro Takemoto of Suzumiya Haruhi no Shoushitsu, Hyouka shows that normal life can be full of small mysteries, be it family history, a student film, or even the withered flowers that make up a ghost story.

(Source: MAL Rewrite)
synonyms: เฮียวกะปริศนาความทรงจำ

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Classic Literature
tags.description: Discusses or adapts a work of classic world literature.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Filmmaking
tags.description: Centers around the art of filmmaking.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Cosplay
tags.description: Features dressing up as a different character or profession.

tags.name: Shrine Maiden
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a shrine maiden.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/162305754) | [Website](http://gatoh.com/)

Noted as the creator of the [Full Metal Panic!](https://anilist.co/manga/40892/) franchise.

Gatou first met [Kouichi Chigira](https://anilist.co/staff/106134/), the director of Full Metal Panic's first season, by accident when he bumped into him in Shinjuku when he was late for work. The two were surprised to later meet each other at [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/)'s offices.

He has also worked as a scriptwriter on a handful of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/)'s shows after their involvement in adapting Full Metal Panic, most notably working as the lead writer on [Hyouka](https://anilist.co/anime/12189/). He also supervised the studio's production of [Amagi Brilliant Park](https://anilist.co/anime/20602/), which was adapted from another light novel of his.

In 2019, Gatou posted controversial remarks to his Twitter about teenage environmental activist Greta Thunberg, but later removed the tweet in response to public backlash and apologized for writing it.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).

__Height:__ 153 cm 
__Agency:__ AXL-ONE

[Profile (AXL-ONE)](https://axl-one.com/talent/sato.htmll) | [Blog](http://ameblo.jp/sato-satomi58) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/satosatomi58) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sugar_me58/) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satomi_Satō) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤聡美)

She is a voice actress from Miyagi Prefecture, Japan currently affiliated with AXL-ONE. She is a graduate of Tokyo Announce Gakuin Performing Arts College. She is also known as Sugar (しゅがぁ, Shugā). She announced her marriage with fellow voice actor, [Takuma Terashima](https://anilist.co/staff/95494/), on July 6, 2017. 

Non-anime roles:
- Signal, N102 - Goddess of Victory: Nikke (VG)
- Dorothy - Arknights (VG)
- Corrin (Female) - Fire Emblem (VG)
- Alfin Reise Arnor - Kiseki Series (VG)
- Ennea - Kiseki Series (VG)
- Escoffier - Genshin Impact (VG)

Yasuhiro Takemoto studied animation at the Yoyogi Animation Academy. After graduating, he started working at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/Kyoto-Animation) for almost his entire animation career, joining the company in 1996. At the company, Yasuhiro was considered one of the most reliable and trustworthy members of the staff. [Nurse Witch Komugi](https://anilist.co/anime/615/Nurse-Witch-Komugichan/) was his directorial debut​ and [Full Metal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/Full-Metal-Panic-Fumoffu/) his first solo directorial debut.

He died in the arson attack at Kyoto Animation's Studio 1 on July 18, 2019.

node.description:
Yasuhiro Takemoto studied animation at the Yoyogi Animation Academy. After graduating, he started working at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/Kyoto-Animation) for almost his entire animation career, joining the company in 1996. At the company, Yasuhiro was considered one of the most reliable and trustworthy members of the staff. [Nurse Witch Komugi](https://anilist.co/anime/615/Nurse-Witch-Komugichan/) was his directorial debut​ and [Full Metal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/Full-Metal-Panic-Fumoffu/) his first solo directorial debut.

He died in the arson attack at Kyoto Animation's Studio 1 on July 18, 2019.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9C%A8%E4%B8%8A%E7%9B%8A%E6%B2%BB) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiji_Kigami)

Yoshiji Kigami was a Japanese director and animator, as well as a board member of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

Kigami was a big fan of Disney movies and [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works from a young age, and this aspired him to become and animator. After working for two years to save money for school, he entered Tokyo Designer Gakuin, a vocational school in Tokyo. He worked part-time in a gas station while attending the school. In 1979, he saw a [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/) recruitment advert in a magazine. He then applied to the studio, got hired, and subsequently dropped out of the vocational school.

In 1982, together with six colleagues, he established his own animation sub-contracting studio by the name Animaru Ya. By the mid '80s, Kigami had made a name for himself in the industry and was getting job offers straight to his name, which led him to working on film such as [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) and [Grave of the Fireflies](https://anilist.co/anime/578/). In 1990, Kigami left Animaru Ya to take care of his mother in his hometown for a year.

After his return to work he joined Kyoto Animation, and became a key factor in the to-be acclaimed animation studio's rapid growth throughout the years. Kigami mainly served as an animator during his career, but also directed, storyboarded and screenwrote numerous episodes and works for the studio. He was also involved in training young animators at the studio's training school.

On July 18, 2019, Kigami was tragically killed alongside 34 of his colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dochibibi) Yukiko Horiguchi is an animator, illustrator and character designer formerly belonging to Kyoto Animation. She joined Kyoto Animation in 2003 after graduating from a junior college (tanki daigaku). She started as inbetweener on Shin-Chan, before making a debut as key animator on the KyoAni in-house OVA Munto. In 2007 she was given the chance to design characters for the anime adaptation of the Lucky Star yon-koma manga. Horiguchi is particularly known for the shape she gives her drawings, resulting in a certain roundness and the distinctly fine outline and peculiar shading. Her characters appear to be very child-like and cute, and full of energy, which is a major appeal to the fans. The illustrator [BUNBUN](https://anilist.co/staff/112785) is her younger brother.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dochibibi) Yukiko Horiguchi is an animator, illustrator and character designer formerly belonging to Kyoto Animation. She joined Kyoto Animation in 2003 after graduating from a junior college (tanki daigaku). She started as inbetweener on Shin-Chan, before making a debut as key animator on the KyoAni in-house OVA Munto. In 2007 she was given the chance to design characters for the anime adaptation of the Lucky Star yon-koma manga. Horiguchi is particularly known for the shape she gives her drawings, resulting in a certain roundness and the distinctly fine outline and peculiar shading. Her characters appear to be very child-like and cute, and full of energy, which is a major appeal to the fans. The illustrator [BUNBUN](https://anilist.co/staff/112785) is her younger brother.

Futoshi Nishiya was a character designer and animator affiliated with Kyoto Animation.

He tragically lost his life alongside 34 colleagues in the Kyoto Animation arson attack on July 18, 2019.

__[Profile (Osawa)](https://osawa-inc.co.jp/women/kayanoai/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/kayanoai_0913) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/kayanoai_0913/) | [YouTube Channel Official Twitter](https://twitter.com/_kayanomi) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0D6qi-Gr5RW7hqOvTEKmAw)__

__Introduction:__
Ai Kayano is a Japanese voice actress and vocalist currently affiliated with Office Osawa.

__Biography:__
Kayano wanted to work in a job that would involve "healing people", leading to initially take up a course at a vocational school. She worked in the beauty industry and became interested in acting after having seen [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477/). While attending school, Kayano continued working in the industry and paid for her tuition.

Kayano began working at Pro-Fit in 2010, voicing two supporting characters in the original video animation [Princess Resurrection](https://anilist.co/anime/9159/). In 2011, she voiced [Meiko "Menma" Honma](https://anilist.co/character/40592/) in [Anohana](https://anilist.co/anime/9989/) and received the Best Rookie Actress award for said role at the 6th Seiyuu Awards. Kayano, [Haruka Tomatsu](https://anilist.co/staff/95890/) and [Saori Hayami](https://anilist.co/staff/95869/) performed the series' ending theme "Secret Base – Kimi ga Kureta Mono (10 years after Ver.)", a cover of a song originally sung by the band Zone.

She is often praised for her vocal range, having voiced a variety of characters such as [Mayaka Ibara](https://anilist.co/character/55137/), [Mashiro Shiina](https://anilist.co/character/61371/), [Darkness](https://anilist.co/character/89363/) and [Akari Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/character/24311/) for example, none of which one would connect to the same voice actress.

**Trivia:**
- Worked part-time at a coffee shop with [Chinatsu Akasaki](https://anilist.co/staff/107652/) before becoming a voice actress.
- She got around 100 suggestions for her nickname in the Anohana radio show, from which she herself picked out Kayanon.

Non-anime roles:
- Atago - Azur Lane
- Graf Zeppelin - Azur Lane
- Kaga - Azur Lane
- Renown - Azur Lane
- Y'shtola Rhul - Final Fantasy XIV

Co-Founder of Kyoto Animation and husband of producer [Youko Hatta](https://anilist.co/staff/103085/).

Started his career as a painter at Shin-Ei Animation in the early '80s.

__[Official Website](http://choucho-net.com/)__ | __[Blog (JP)](http://ameblo.jp/choucho621/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/choucho_)__ | __[NicoNico](https://www.nicovideo.jp/user/3416529) | [Instragram](https://www.instagram.com/choucho621/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGK8Fhw3qDEtHaivTsxfGgg)__ | __[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/5t7eQ2d1UmzfIr9oWQ538Y?autoplay=true)__

__Introduction:__
ChouCho is a Japanese singer-utaite known for doing vocal covers of Vocaloid songs on NicoNico Douga, in addition to making frequent appearances in anime with original songs.

__Biography:__
In 2007, she initially formed the band Lotus*Lotus (stylized as ロータス★ロータス) while still in high school, the band performed covers of songs from anime, then starting from June 2008 she first appeared on NicoNico with her cover of the song "[Black★Rock Shooter](https://www.nicovideo.jp/watch/sm3706654)" under stage name ちょうちょ. In 2011, she made her first major debut under record label Lantis, singing the opening theme song to the anime [Kamisama no Memochou](https://anilist.co/anime/10568/Kamisama-no-Memochou/), titled "[Kawaru Mirai](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Un9UiVL6Dms)", and later in the same year she reappeared with the opening theme song to the anime [Mashiroiro Symphony](https://anilist.co/anime/10397/Mashiroiro-Symphony-The-Color-of-Lovers), titled "[Authentic Symphony](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzGWaS0lyIo)", then in 2012, after releasing her 4th single titled "[Yasashisa no Riyuu](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0hJiMN4Csjw)", she changed her stage name from ちょうちょ to ChouCho. The song was also used as the 1st opening theme song to the anime [Hyouka](https://anilist.co/anime/12189/Hyouka/), which released in 2012.

Her last upload to NicoNico was an album released with Comiket 81, titled "[Little Nostalgia](https://www.nicovideo.jp/watch/sm16484379)", featuring 5 songs: Breeze, Beautiful World (Acoustic Ver.), Hana to Hoshi no Monogatari, North York and Under the Maple Tree.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/honobu_yonezawa) | [Blog](http://pandreamium.sblo.jp/)

Yonezawa Honobu is a Japanese mystery fiction writer, mostly known for stories like The Incite Mill (adapted as a movie), Kaitou X kara no Chousenjou and Mangan (both adapted as TV dramas) and the Koten-bu series, that gave origin to the acclaimed anime adaptation titled Hyouka.
